div.head: General
div.p: The Ġāmid are a large tribe consisting of many sub-tribes. The bilād Ġāmid lie in the south-western highlands of the Hedjaz in Saudi Arabia. Their provincial capital is al-Bāḥa. Since the establishment of the Saudi state in 1925, they are administered together with the Zahrān. Formerly, their capital was Balǧurašī, and before 1925, it was aẓ-Ẓafīr. Today, members of the the Ghamid can be found in Oman, Yemen, Jordan, Iraq and elsewhere. They are said to descend from Ġāmid ibn ˁAbdullah of al-Azd of the Yemenite Qaḥṭān. They are closely related to the neighbouring Zahrān. In terms of religion, they are Sunni muslims of the Ḥanbalī school.

div.head: Research history
div.p: Nadwi 1968 is an unpublished PhD thesis. It provides a description of phonology, morphology and syntax, but does not distinguish between Ġāmid and Zahrān speakers and is regarded as an unreliable source. Toll 1983 is a concise monograph on the Ġāmidī dialect, for which a questionnaire and recorded texts were used. It is based on fieldwork from the early 1970s. Verb and pronoun paradigms are extracted entirely from recorded texts. It also deals with syllable structure and stress. A third of the book (i.e. some 20 pages) is dedicated to texts in phonological and transcription and their translation. The dialect of the Bani Ghāmid is included in Prochazka 1988 and in Behnstedt’s 2016 dialect atlas.
